intro: Beringeria, commonly known as the Beringian flora, refers to a group of plant species that were once widespread across the Bering Land Bridge during the last Ice Age. These plants adapted to the cold, arid conditions of the region, developing features such as small leaves and thick cuticles to minimize water loss. Many Beringian plants are now extinct, with only a few surviving in isolated pockets of the modern-day Arctic and subarctic regions. The study of Beringeria provides valuable insights into ancient ecosystems and climate change. Botanists use fossil pollen and genetic analysis to reconstruct the diversity and distribution of these plants.
